definitions.definition: A state of safety, protection or shelter.
A place providing safety, protection or shelter.
Something or someone turned to for safety or assistance; a recourse or resort.
An expedient to secure protection or defence.
A refuge island.
To return to a place of shelter.
To shelter; to protect.
A number representing the position of a point along a line, arc, or similar one-dimensional figure.
definitions.example: Give me your coordinates and we'll come and rescue you.

definitions.definition: Something that is equal to another thing.
(in the plural) Coordinated clothes.
To synchronize (activities).
definitions.example: I was playing tennis for the first time, and it was difficult to coordinate.

definitions.definition: To match (objects, especially clothes).
definitions.example: The outfit you're wearing doesn't coordinate.

definitions.definition: Of the same rank; equal.
definitions.example: two coordinate terms

definitions.definition: A diminutive of the pale, usually appearing in pairs on either side of a pale.
To support, to back, to give one's approval to, especially officially or by signature.
To write one's signature on the back of a cheque, or other negotiable instrument, when transferring it to a third party, or cashing it.
To give an endorsement.
To confer with others in order to come to terms or reach an agreement.
To arrange or settle something by mutual agreement.
definitions.example: The client and server computers must first negotiate a network protocol to be used.

definitions.definition: To succeed in coping with, or getting over something.
definitions.example: Although the car was quite rickety, he could negotiate the curves very well.

definitions.definition: To transfer to another person with all the rights of the original holder; to pass, as a bill.
To transact business; to carry on trade.
To intrigue; to scheme.
To yield or suffer; to surrender; to grant
definitions.example: He conceded the race once it was clear he could not win.

definitions.definition: To grant, as a right or privilege; to make concession of.
To admit to be true; to acknowledge.
To yield or make concession.
To have a goal or point scored against
(of a bowler) to have runs scored off of one's bowling.
To grow or increase stature; to grow vigorously or luxuriantly, to flourish.
definitions.example: Not all animals thrive well in captivity.

definitions.definition: To increase in wealth or success; to prosper, be profitable.
definitions.example: Since expanding in June, the business has really thrived.

definitions.definition: The work of one who makes images or visible representation of objects.
Imitation work.
Images in general, or en masse.
Unreal show; imitation; appearance.
The work of the imagination or fancy; false ideas; imaginary phantasms.
Rhetorical decoration in writing or speaking; vivid descriptions presenting or suggesting images of sensible objects; figures in discourse.
To take a risk, with the potential of a positive outcome.
To play risky games, especially casino games, for monetary gain.
To risk (something) for potential gain.
definitions.example: He gambled his reputation on the outcome.

definitions.definition: To interact with equipment at a casino
An activity characterised by a balance between winning and losing that is governed by a mixture of skill and chance, usually with money wagered on the outcome.
One who occupationally works with records, accounts, letters, etc.; an office worker.
A facilitator of a Quaker meeting for business affairs.
In the Church of England, the layman that assists in the church service, especially in reading the responses (also called parish clerk).
A cleric or clergyman (the legal title for clergy of the Church of England is "Clerk in Holy Orders", still used in legal documents and cherished by some of their number).
A scholar.
To act as a clerk, to perform the duties or functions of a clerk
definitions.example: The law school graduate clerked for the supreme court judge for the summer.

definitions.definition: Rapid circular motion.
definitions.example: He put some spin on the cue ball.

definitions.definition: A quantum angular momentum associated with subatomic particles, which also creates a magnetic moment.
A favourable comment or interpretation intended to bias opinion on an otherwise unpleasant situation.
definitions.example: The politician was mocked in the press for his reliance on spin rather than facts.

definitions.definition: Rotation of the ball as it flies through the air; sideways movement of the ball as it bounces.
A condition of flight where a stalled aircraft is simultaneously pitching, yawing and rolling in a spinning motion.
A brief trip by vehicle, especially one made for pleasure.
definitions.example: I'm off out for a spin in my new sports car.

definitions.definition: A bundle of spun material; a mass of strands and filaments.
A single play of a record by a radio station.
A search of a prisoner's cell for forbidden articles.
Unmarried woman, spinster.
The use of an exercise bicycle, especially as part of a gym class.
To rotate, revolve, gyrate (usually quickly); to partially or completely rotate to face another direction.
definitions.example: I spun myself around a few times.

definitions.definition: To make yarn by twisting and winding fibers together.
definitions.example: They spin the cotton into thread.

definitions.definition: To present, describe, or interpret, or to introduce a bias or slant, so as to give something a favorable or advantageous appearance.
(of a bowler) To make the ball move sideways when it bounces on the pitch.
(of a ball) To move sideways when bouncing.
To form into thin strips or ribbons, as with sugar
To form (a web, a cocoon, silk, etc.) from threads produced by the extrusion of a viscid, transparent liquid, which hardens on coming into contact with the air; said of the spider, the silkworm, etc.
To shape, as malleable sheet metal, into a hollow form, by bending or buckling it by pressing against it with a smooth hand tool or roller while the metal revolves, as in a lathe.
To move swiftly.
definitions.example: to spin along the road in a carriage, on a bicycle, etc.

definitions.definition: To stream or issue in a thread or a small current or jet.
definitions.example: Blood spins from a vein.

definitions.definition: To wait in a loop until some condition becomes true.
To play (vinyl records, etc.) as a disc jockey.
To use an exercise bicycle, especially as part of a gym class.
An abnormal condition in journal bearings where the bearing seizes to the shaft that is rotating and rotates inside the journal, destroying both the shaft and the journal.
The act of turning around a centre or an axis.
definitions.example: The earth's rotation about its axis is responsible for its being slightly oblate rather than a sphere.

definitions.definition: A single complete cycle around a centre or an axis.
definitions.example: Earth's moon completes a rotation every twenty-seven days or so.

definitions.definition: A regular variation in a sequence, such as to even-out wear, or people taking turns in a task; a duty roster.
definitions.example: In rotation, each member of the group would be responsible for the beacon fire.

definitions.definition: An operation on a metric space that is a continuous isometry and fixes at least one point.
definitions.example: The function mapping (x,y) to (−y,x) is a rotation.

definitions.definition: The set of starting pitchers of a team.
The step during takeoff when the pilot commands the vehicle to lift the nose wheel off the ground during the takeoff roll. (see also: V2)
Repeated play on a radio station, etc.
definitions.example: The new single enjoyed heavy rotation on MTV.

definitions.definition: The act of soaring.
An upward flight.
To fly high with little effort, like a bird.
To mount upward on wings, or as on wings.
To remain aloft by means of a glider or other unpowered aircraft.
To rise, especially rapidly or unusually high.
definitions.example: The pump prices soared into new heights as the strike continued.

definitions.definition: To rise in thought, spirits, or imagination; to be exalted in mood.
Something that is predictable, necessary, or cannot be avoided.
Impossible to avoid or prevent.
definitions.example: We were going so fast that the collision was inevitable.

definitions.definition: Predictable, or always happening.
definitions.example: My outburst met with the inevitable punishment.

definitions.definition: Of or relating to the biological theory of evolution.
definitions.example: The evolutionary history of marine mammals includes land-dwelling ancestors.

definitions.definition: Having formal similarities to the biological theory of evolution.
Of a body in motion: the tendency of a body to maintain its inertial motion; the product of its mass and velocity.
The impetus, either of a body in motion, or of an idea or course of events; a moment.
A male deer, antelope, sheep, goat, rabbit, hare, and sometimes the male of other animals such as the hamster, ferret and shad.
An uncastrated sheep, a ram.
A young buck; an adventurous, impetuous, dashing, or high-spirited young man.
A fop or dandy.
A black or Native American man.
A dollar (one hundred cents).
definitions.example: Can I borrow five bucks?

definitions.definition: A rand (currency unit).
(by extension) Money.
definitions.example: Corporations will do anything to make a buck.

definitions.definition: One hundred.
definitions.example: That skinny guy? C'mon, he can't weigh more than a buck and a quarter [125 pounds].

definitions.definition: An object of various types, placed on a table to indicate turn or status; such as a brass object, placed in rotation on a US Navy wardroom dining table to indicate which officer is to be served first, or an item passed around a poker table indicating the dealer or placed in the pot to remind the winner of some privilege or obligation when his or her turn to deal next comes.
(in certain metaphors or phrases) Blame; responsibility; scapegoating; finger-pointing.
definitions.example: pass the buck

definitions.definition: The body of a post mill, particularly in East Anglia. See Wikipedia:Windmill machinery.
One million dollars.
A euro.
A frame on which firewood is sawed; a sawhorse; a sawbuck.
A leather-covered frame used for gymnastic vaulting
A wood or metal frame used by automotive customizers and restorers to assist in the shaping of sheet metal bodywork. See Street Rodder "Making a Wood Buck".
To copulate, as bucks and does.
A type of African American traditional clogging.
The generally sterile male or female hybrid offspring of a male donkey and a female horse.
The generally sterile hybrid offspring of any two species of animals.
A hybrid plant.
A stubborn person.
A person paid to smuggle drugs.
A coin or medal minted with obverse and reverse designs not normally seen on the same piece, either intentionally or in error.
A MMORPG character, or NPC companion in a tabletop RPG, used mainly to store extra inventory for the owner's primary character.
Any of a group of cocktails involving ginger ale or ginger beer, citrus juice, and various liquors.
A kind of triangular sail for a yacht.
A kind of cotton-spinning machine.
A shoe that has no fitting or strap around the heel, but which covers the foot.
To bend; buckle.

(of a horse or similar saddle or pack animal) To leap upward arching its back, coming down with head low and forelegs stiff, forcefully kicking its hind legs upward, often in an attempt to dislodge or throw a rider or pack.
(of a horse or similar saddle or pack animal) To throw (a rider or pack) by bucking.
To subject to a mode of punishment which consists of tying the wrists together, passing the arms over the bent knees, and putting a stick across the arms and in the angle formed by the knees.
(by extension) To resist obstinately; oppose or object strongly.
definitions.example: The vice president bucked at the board's latest solution.

definitions.definition: (by extension) To move or operate in a sharp, jerking, or uneven manner.
definitions.example: The motor bucked and sputtered before dying completely.

definitions.definition: (by extension) To overcome or shed (e.g., an impediment or expectation), in pursuit of a goal; to force a way through despite (an obstacle); to resist or proceed against.
definitions.example: John is really bucking the odds on that risky business venture. He's doing quite well.

definitions.definition: (riveting) To press a reinforcing device (bucking bar) against (the force of a rivet) in order to absorb vibration and increase expansion. See Wikipedia: Rivet:Installation.
To saw a felled tree into shorter lengths, as for firewood.
To output a voltage that is lower than the input voltage. See Wikipedia: Buck converter
The beech tree.
Lye or suds in which cloth is soaked in the operation of bleaching, or in which clothes are washed.
The cloth or clothes soaked or washed.
To soak, steep or boil in lye or suds, as part of the bleaching process.
To wash (clothes) in lye or suds, or, in later usage, by beating them on stones in running water.
To break up or pulverize, as ores.
The fifth major tone of a musical scale (five major steps above the note in question); thus G is the dominant of C, A of D, and so on.
The triad built on the dominant tone.
A gene that is dominant.
A species or organism that is dominant.
(BDSM) The dominating partner in sadomasochistic sexual activity.
Ruling; governing; prevailing
definitions.example: The dominant party controlled the government.

definitions.definition: Predominant, common, prevalent, of greatest importance.
definitions.example: The dominant plants of the Carboniferous were lycopods and early conifers.

definitions.definition: Designating the follicle which will survive atresia and permit ovulation.
An event or occurrence that signifies an ending.
A feeling of completeness; the experience of an emotional conclusion, usually to a difficult period.
A device to facilitate temporary and repeatable opening and closing.

An abstraction that represents a function within an environment, a context consisting of the variables that are both bound at a particular time during the execution of the program and that are within the function's scope.
The smallest set that both includes a given subset and possesses some given property.
(of a set) The smallest closed set which contains the given set.
The act of shutting; a closing.
definitions.example: the closure of a door, or of a chink

definitions.definition: That which closes or shuts; that by which separate parts are fastened or closed.
That which encloses or confines; an enclosure.
A method of ending a parliamentary debate and securing an immediate vote upon a measure before a legislative body.
The process whereby the reader of a comic book infers the sequence of events by looking at the picture panels.
To break or disregard (a rule or convention).
definitions.example: Accessing unauthorized files violates security protocol.

definitions.definition: To rape.
To cite (a person) for a parole violation.
A person convicted of a crime by a judicial body.
A person deported to a penal colony.
The convict cichlid (Amatitlania nigrofasciata), also known as the zebra cichlid, a popular aquarium fish, with stripes that resemble a prison uniform.
A common name for the sheepshead (Archosargus probatocephalus), owing to its black and gray stripes.
To find guilty
definitions.example: His remarks convicted him of a lack of sensitivity.

definitions.definition: (esp. religious) to convince, persuade; to cause (someone) to believe in (something)
The condition of failing to meet an obligation.
definitions.example: He failed to make payments on time and is now in default.

definitions.definition: The original software programming settings as set by the factory
A loss incurred by failing to compete.
definitions.example: The team's three losses include one default.

definitions.definition: A selection made in the absence of an alternative.
definitions.example: The man became the leader of the group as a default.

definitions.definition: A value used when none has been given; a tentative value or standard that is presumed.
definitions.example: If you don't specify a number of items, the default is 1.

definitions.definition: The failure of a defendant to appear and answer a summons and complaint.
A failing or failure; omission of that which ought to be done; neglect to do what duty or law requires.
definitions.example: This evil has happened through the governor's default.

definitions.definition: Lack; absence.
Fault; offence; wrong act.
To fail to meet an obligation.
definitions.example: If you do not make your payments, you will default on your loan.

definitions.definition: To lose a competition by failing to compete.
definitions.example: If you refuse to wear a proper uniform, you will not be allowed to compete and will default this match.

definitions.definition: To assume a value when none was given; to presume a tentative value or standard.
definitions.example: If you don't specify a number of items, it defaults to 1.

definitions.definition: To fail to appear and answer a summons and complaint.
An act or instance of nominating.
A device or means by which a person or thing is nominated.
Someone or something that is awkward.
Lacking dexterity in the use of the hands, or of instruments.
definitions.example: John was awkward at performing the trick. He'll have to practice to improve.

definitions.definition: Not easily managed or effected; embarrassing.
definitions.example: An awkward silence had fallen.

definitions.definition: Lacking social skills, or uncomfortable with social interaction.
definitions.example: I'm very awkward at parties.

definitions.definition: Perverse; adverse; difficult to handle.
definitions.example: He's a right awkward chap.

definitions.definition: In a backwards direction.
To render fit, suitable, or correspondent; to adapt.
definitions.example: to accommodate ourselves to circumstances

definitions.definition: To cause to come to agreement; to bring about harmony; to reconcile.
definitions.example: to accommodate differences

definitions.definition: To provide housing for.
definitions.example: to accommodate an old friend for a week

definitions.definition: To provide with something desired, needed, or convenient.
definitions.example: to accommodate a friend with a loan

definitions.definition: To do a favor or service for; to oblige.
To show the correspondence of; to apply or make suit by analogy; to adapt or fit, as teachings to accidental circumstances, statements to facts, etc.
definitions.example: to accommodate prophecy to events

definitions.definition: To give consideration to; to allow for.
To contain comfortably; to have space for.
definitions.example: This venue accommodates three hundred people.

definitions.definition: To adapt oneself; to be conformable or adapted; become adjusted.
Suitable; fit; adapted; as, means accommodate to end.
Following, afterwards in either time or place.
Accordingly, therefore (implying a logical connection or deduction).
To place abreast, or in a line.
To have a ranking.
definitions.example: Their defense ranked third in the league.

definitions.definition: To assign a suitable place in a class or order; to classify.
To take rank of; to outrank.
One’s relative placement in a list.
(in combination) Having a specified rank.
Superior in rank.
To disallow; to proscribe.
definitions.example: Smoking in the restaurant is forbidden.

definitions.definition: (ditransitive) To deny, exclude from, or warn off, by express command.
To oppose, hinder, or prevent, as if by an effectual command.
definitions.example: An impassable river forbids the approach of the army.

definitions.definition: To accurse; to blast.
To defy; to challenge.
definitions.example: What part of "no" do you forbid to understand?

definitions.definition: A person or animal who browses.
A person who examines goods for sale but purchases nothing.
A web browser.
The sound of a violent impact; a violent striking together.
definitions.example: I could hear the screech of the brakes, then the horrible smash of cars colliding.

definitions.definition: A traffic collision.
definitions.example: The driver and two passengers were badly injured in the smash.

definitions.definition: Something very successful or popular (as music, food, fashion, etc); a hit.
definitions.example: This new show is sure to be a smash.

definitions.definition: A very hard overhead shot hit sharply downward.
definitions.example: A smash may not be as pretty as a good half volley, but it can still win points.

definitions.definition: A bankruptcy.
A kind of julep cocktail containing chunks of fresh fruit that can be eaten after finishing the drink.
To break (something brittle) violently.
definitions.example: The demolition team smashed the buildings to rubble.

definitions.definition: To be destroyed by being smashed.
definitions.example: The crockery smashed as it hit the floor.

definitions.definition: To hit extremely hard.
definitions.example: Bonds smashed the ball 467 feet, the second longest home run in the history of the park.

definitions.definition: To ruin completely and suddenly.
definitions.example: The news smashed any hopes of a reunion.

definitions.definition: To defeat overwhelmingly; to gain a comprehensive success.
definitions.example: I really smashed that English exam.

definitions.definition: To deform through continuous pressure.
definitions.example: I slowly smashed the modeling clay flat with the palm of my hand.

definitions.definition: To have sexual intercourse with.
definitions.example: Would you smash her?

definitions.definition: In a strict manner.
definitions.example: He adhered strictly to the diet his doctor prescribed.

definitions.definition: In a limited manner; only
In a narrow or limited sense.
definitions.example: That term refers strictly to smaller birds.

definitions.definition: In a manner that applies to every member of a set or every interval of a function
A prosecuting attorney.
definitions.example: Annie Jay was the Wisconsin government prosecutor in the trial of a man for forging his client's signature.

definitions.definition: A person, as a complainant, victim, or chief witness, who institutes prosecution in a criminal proceeding.
definitions.example: The prosecutor got the witness to admit he was lying.

definitions.definition: A very young human being, from birth to somewhere between six months and two years of age, needing almost constant care and/or attention.
A minor.
A noble or aristocratic youth.
To bear or bring forth (a child); to produce, in general.
Local coherence.
Correspondence or compatibility.
Reliability or uniformity; the quality of being consistent.
definitions.example: They want to achieve a high degree of consistency in their process and their product.

definitions.definition: The degree of viscosity of something.
definitions.example: Mix it until it has the consistency of a thick paste.

definitions.definition: Freedom from contradiction; the state of a system of axioms such that none of the propositions deduced from them are mutually contradictory.
Firmness of constitution or character; substantiality; durability; persistency.
The condition of being stunned.
That which stuns; a shock; a stupefying blow.
A person who lacks intelligence.
The effect on the cue ball where the ball is hit without topspin, backspin or sidespin.
definitions.example: Williams will need a lot of stun to avoid going in the middle pocket

definitions.definition: To incapacitate; especially by inducing disorientation or unconsciousness.
definitions.example: Bill tried to stun the snake by striking it on the head.

definitions.definition: To shock or surprise.
definitions.example: He stood there stunned, looking at the beautiful, breath-taking sunrise.

definitions.definition: To hit the cue ball so that it slides without topspin or backspin (and with or without sidespin) and continues at a natural angle after contact with the object ball
The opposite of something.
definitions.example: We believed the Chinese weren't ready for us. In fact, the reverse was true.

definitions.definition: The act of going backwards; a reversal.
A piece of misfortune; a setback.
The tails side of a coin, or the side of a medal or badge that is opposite the obverse.
The side of something facing away from a viewer, or from what is considered the front; the other side.
The gear setting of an automobile that makes it travel backwards.
A thrust in fencing made with a backward turn of the hand; a backhanded stroke.
A turn or fold made in bandaging, by which the direction of the bandage is changed.
To turn something around so that it faces the opposite direction or runs in the opposite sequence.
definitions.example: to reverse a portion of video footage

definitions.definition: To turn something inside out or upside down.
To transpose the positions of two things.
To change totally; to alter to the opposite.
To return, come back.
To turn away; to cause to depart.
To cause to return; to recall.
To revoke a law, or to change a decision into its opposite.
definitions.example: to reverse a judgment, sentence, or decree

definitions.definition: To cause a mechanism or a vehicle to operate or move in the opposite direction to normal.
To change the direction of a reaction such that the products become the reactants and vice-versa.
To place a set of points in the reverse position
(of points) to move from the normal position to the reverse position
To overthrow; to subvert.
Opposite, contrary; going in the opposite direction.
definitions.example: The mirror showed us a reverse view of the scene.

definitions.definition: Pertaining to engines, vehicle movement etc. moving in a direction opposite to the usual direction.
definitions.example: He selected reverse gear.

definitions.definition: (of points) To be in the non-default position; to be set for the lesser-used route.
Turned upside down; greatly disturbed.
Reversed.
definitions.example: a reverse shell

definitions.definition: In which cDNA synthetization is obtained from an RNA template.
In a reverse way or direction; in reverse; upside-down.
Any object used as a weapon by being thrown or fired through the air, such as stone, arrow or bullet.
definitions.example: The Rhodians, who used leaden bullets, were able to project their missiles twice as far as the Persian slingers, who used large stones.

definitions.definition: A self-propelled projectile whose trajectory can be adjusted after it is launched.
definitions.example: That missile is explosive enough to kill hundreds.

definitions.definition: An object, act or words believed to have magic power (usually carries a positive connotation).
definitions.example: It works like a charm.

definitions.definition: The ability to persuade, delight or arouse admiration; often constructed in the plural.
definitions.example: He had great personal charm.

definitions.definition: A small trinket on a bracelet or chain, etc., traditionally supposed to confer luck upon the wearer.
definitions.example: She wears a charm bracelet on her wrist.

definitions.definition: A quantum number of hadrons determined by the number of charm quarks and antiquarks.
A second-order measure of derivative price sensitivity, expressed as the instantaneous rate of change of delta with respect to time.
To seduce, persuade or fascinate someone or something.
definitions.example: He charmed her with his dashing tales of his days as a sailor.

definitions.definition: To use a magical charm upon; to subdue, control, or summon by incantation or supernatural influence.
definitions.example: After winning three games while wearing the chain, Dan began to think it had been charmed.

definitions.definition: To protect with, or make invulnerable by, spells, charms, or supernatural influences.
definitions.example: She led a charmed life.

definitions.definition: To make music upon.
To subdue or overcome by some secret power, or by that which gives pleasure; to allay; to soothe.
The mixed sound of many voices, especially of birds or children.
A flock, group (especially of finches).
Of the nature of a disaster; calamitous.
Foreboding disaster; ill-omened.
A projectile consisting of a shaft, a point and a tail with stabilizing fins that is shot from a bow.
A sign or symbol used to indicate a direction (e.g. →).
A directed edge.
A dart.
The -> symbol, which has specific meanings in various programming languages.
The inflorescence or tassel of a mature sugar cane plant.
To move swiftly and directly (like an arrow)
To let fly swiftly and directly
(of a sugar cane plant) To develop an inflorescence.
To navigate using the arrow keys.
definitions.example: Arrow left until you reach the start of the text you want to delete.

definitions.definition: The process of revising:
A changed edition, or new version; a modification.
A story corrected or expanded by a writer commissioned by the original author.
definitions.example: A revision story

definitions.definition: To provide with a new vision.
definitions.example: What philosophy needs is to be revised with a more hopeful, engaged inspirational point of view.

definitions.definition: To part, separate or divide.
definitions.example: A metal comb shed her golden hair.

definitions.definition: To part with, separate from, leave off; cast off, let fall, be divested of.
definitions.example: When we found the snake, it was in the process of shedding its skin.

definitions.definition: To pour; to make flow.
To allow to flow or fall.
definitions.example: A tarpaulin sheds water.

definitions.definition: To radiate, cast, give off (light); see also shed light on.
definitions.example: Can you shed any light on this problem?

definitions.definition: To pour forth, give off, impart.
To fall in drops; to pour.
To sprinkle; to intersperse; to cover.
To divide, as the warp threads, so as to form a shed, or passageway, for the shuttle.
An area between upper and lower warp yarns through which the weft is woven.
A distinction or dividing-line.
A parting in the hair.
The top of the head.
An area of land as distinguished from those around it.
A slight or temporary structure built to shade or shelter something; a structure usually open in front; an outbuilding; a hut.
definitions.example: a wagon shed; a wood shed; a garden shed

definitions.definition: A large temporary open structure for reception of goods.
An automobile which is old, worn-out, slow, or otherwise of poor quality.
(rail transportation) A British Rail Class 66 locomotive.
To place or allocate a vehicle, such as a locomotive, in or to a depot or shed.
To suddenly excite someone, or to give someone great pleasure; to (figuratively) electrify; to experience such a sensation.
To (cause something to) tremble or quiver.
To perforate by a pointed instrument; to bore; to transfix; to drill.
To hurl; to throw; to cast.
To drill and thread in one operation, using a tool bit that cuts the hole and the threads in one series of computer-controlled movements.
Extremely excited or delighted.
definitions.example: Ben was thrilled to lead the game.

definitions.definition: Responsibility for wrongdoing.
The state of having been found guilty or admitted guilt in legal proceedings.
The regret of having done wrong.
To commit offenses; act criminally.
To cause someone to feel guilt, particularly in order to influence their behaviour.
definitions.example: He didn't want to do it, but his wife guilted him into it.

definitions.definition: Originally, a small ball placed in a container to cast a vote; now, by extension, a piece of paper or card used for this purpose, or some other means used to signify a vote.
The process of voting, especially in secret; a round of voting.
The total of all the votes cast in an election.
A list of candidates running for office; a ticket.
To vote or decide by ballot.
definitions.example: to ballot for a candidate

definitions.definition: To draw lots.
A berry.
Laurus nobilis, a tree or shrub of the family Lauraceae, having dark green leaves and berries.
Bay leaf, the leaf of this or certain other species of tree or shrub, used as a herb.
(in the plural) The leaves of this shrub, woven into a garland used to reward a champion or victor; hence, fame, victory.
A tract covered with bay trees.
A kind of mahogany obtained from Campeche in Mexico.
A body of water (especially the sea) more or less three-quarters surrounded by land.
A bank or dam to keep back water.
An opening in a wall, especially between two columns.
An internal recess; a compartment or area surrounded on three sides.
The distance between two supports in a vault or building with a pitched roof.
Each of the spaces, port and starboard, between decks, forward of the bitts, in sailing warships.
A bay platform.
A bay window.
The excited howling of dogs when hunting or being attacked.
(by extension) The climactic confrontation between hunting-dogs and their prey.
A state of being obliged to face an antagonist or a difficulty, when escape has become impossible.
To howl.
To bark at; hence, to follow with barking; to bring or drive to bay.

definitions.definition: To pursue noisily, like a pack of hounds.
A brown colour/color of the coat of some horses.
A horse of this color.
Of a reddish-brown colour (especially of horses).
To recognize someone or something as different from others based on its characteristics.
To see someone or something clearly or distinctly.
To make oneself noticeably different or better from others through accomplishments.

definitions.definition: To make to differ.
The act of converting something or someone.
definitions.example: His conversion to Christianity

definitions.definition: A software product converted from one platform to another.
A chemical reaction wherein a substrate is transformed into a product.
A free kick, after scoring a try, worth two points.
An extra point (or two) scored by kicking a field goal or carrying the ball into the end zone after scoring a touchdown.
An online advertising performance metric representing a visitor performing whatever the intended result of an ad is defined to be.

Under the common law, the tort of the taking of someone's personal property with intent to permanently deprive them of it, or damaging property to the extent that the owner is deprived of the utility of that property, thus making the tortfeasor liable for the entire value of the property.

definitions.definition: The process whereby a new word is created without changing the form, often by allowing the word to function as a new part of speech.
The act of turning round; revolution; rotation.
The act of interchanging the terms of a proposition, as by putting the subject in the place of the predicate, or vice versa.
A change or reduction of the form or value of a proposition.
definitions.example: the conversion of equations; the conversion of proportions

definitions.definition: The offering of anything to a god; a consecratory rite.
The destruction or surrender of anything for the sake of something else; the devotion of something desirable to something higher, or to a calling deemed more pressing.
definitions.example: the sacrifice of one's spare time in order to volunteer

definitions.definition: Something sacrificed.
A loss of profit.
A sale at a price less than the cost or the actual value.
To offer (something) as a gift to a deity.
To give away (something valuable) to get at least a possibility of gaining something else of value (such as self-respect, trust, love, freedom, prosperity), or to avoid an even greater loss.
definitions.example: Venison has many advantages over meat from factory farms, although it still requires a hunter to sacrifice the life of a deer.

definitions.definition: To trade (a value of higher worth) for something of lesser worth in order to gain something else valued more, such as an ally or business relationship, or to avoid an even greater loss; to sell without profit to gain something other than money.
To intentionally give up (a piece) in order to improve one’s position on the board.
To advance (a runner on base) by batting the ball so it can be caught or fielded, placing the batter out, but with insufficient time to put the runner out.
To sell at a price less than the cost or actual value.
To destroy; to kill.
The morning twilight period immediately before sunrise.
The rising of the sun.
The time when the sun rises.
definitions.example: She rose before dawn to meet the train.

definitions.definition: The earliest phase of something.
definitions.example: the dawn of civilization

definitions.definition: To begin to brighten with daylight.
definitions.example: A new day dawns.

definitions.definition: To start to appear or be realized.
definitions.example: I don’t want to be there when the truth dawns on him.

definitions.definition: To begin to give promise; to begin to appear or to expand.
An advocate of a society based on the common ownership of property; a proponent of communism.
Any revolutionary or subversive radical.
Of, relating to, supporting, or advocating communism.
A wise and trusted counselor or teacher
To act as someone's mentor
The theory, practice and technology of charting a course for a ship, aircraft or spaceship or (colloquially) road vehicle.
Traffic or travel by vessel, especially commercial shipping.
A canal.
A structure built for commemorative or symbolic reasons, or as a memorial; a commemoration.
definitions.example: There is a monument on the town green to the soldiers who died in World War I.

definitions.definition: An important site owned by the community as a whole.
An exceptional or proud achievement.
An important burial vault or tomb.
A legal document.
A surveying reference point marked by a permanently fixed marker (a survey monument).
A pile of stones left by a prospector to claim ownership of ore etc. found in a mine.
To mark or memorialize with a monument.
The act of animating, or giving life or spirit.
(in the sense of a cartoon) The technique of making inanimate objects or drawings appear to move in motion pictures or computer graphics; the object (film, computer game, etc.) so produced
The state of being lively, brisk, or full of spirit and vigor; vivacity; spiritedness
definitions.example: He recited the story with great animation.

definitions.definition: The condition of being animate or alive.
Conversion from the inanimate to animate grammatical category
Argument, contest, debate, strife, struggle.
A point maintained in an argument, or a line of argument taken in its support; the subject matter of discussion of strife; a position taken or contended for.
definitions.example: It is my contention that state lotteries are taxes on stupid people.

definitions.definition: Competition by parts of a system or its users for a limited resource.
Something possessing structure or form.
The act of assembling a group or structure.
The process during which something comes into being and gains its characteristics.
A rock or face of a mountain.
A grouping of military units or smaller formations under a command, such as a brigade, division, wing, etc.
An arrangement of moving troops, ships, or aircraft, such as a wedge, line abreast, or echelon. Often "in formation".
An arrangement of players designed to facilitate certain plays.
The process of influencing or guiding a person to a deeper understanding of a particular vocation.
A structure made of two categories, two functors from the first to the second category, and a transformation from one of the functors to the other.
At some time in the past
Previously; once
(degree) By a small margin.
(degree) Almost not at all.
definitions.example: The plane is so far away now I can barely see it.

definitions.definition: Merely.
A spell or ability that restores hit points or removes a status ailment.
Health

definitions.example: Bandages allow cuts to heal.

definitions.definition: To reconcile, as a breach or difference; to make whole; to free from guilt.

definitions.definition: To make better from a disease, wound, etc.; to revive or cure.
definitions.example: This bandage will heal your cut.

definitions.example: Bandages allow cuts to heal.

definitions.definition: To reconcile, as a breach or difference; to make whole; to free from guilt.

definitions.definition: To hide, conceal, and keep secret, especially for a secret society (such as the masons).
(now especially in the phrase "hele in") To cover or conceal (a seedling, plant, roots, etc).
The act of excepting or excluding; exclusion; restriction by taking out something which would otherwise be included, as in a class, statement, rule.
That which is excepted or taken out from others; a person, thing, or case, specified as distinct, or not included.
definitions.example: That rule is usually true, but there are a few exceptions.

definitions.definition: An objection, on legal grounds; also, as in conveyancing, a clause by which the grantor excepts or reserves something before the right is transferred.
An objection; cavil; dissent; disapprobation; offense; cause of offense; — usually followed by to or against.
An interruption in normal processing, typically caused by an error condition, that can be handled by another part of the program.
The act of recovering data or a system from a backup.
definitions.example: We backed up the data successfully, but the restore failed.

definitions.definition: To reestablish, or bring back into existence.
definitions.example: He restored my lost faith in him by doing a good deed.

definitions.definition: To bring back to good condition from a state of decay or ruin.
To give or bring back (that which has been lost or taken); to bring back to the owner; to replace.
To give in place of, or as restitution for.
To recover (data, etc.) from a backup.
definitions.example: There was a crash last night, and we're still restoring the file system.

definitions.definition: To bring (a note) back to its original signification.
To make good; to make amends for.
An object, usually made of glass, that focuses or defocuses the light that passes through it.
A device which focuses or defocuses electron beams.
A convex shape bounded by two circular arcs, joined at their endpoints, the corresponding concave shape being a lune.
A genus of the legume family; its bean.
The transparent crystalline structure in the eye.
(earth science) A body of rock, ice, or water shaped like a convex lens.
A construct used in statically-typed functional programming languages to access nested data structures.
(by extension) A way of looking, literally or figuratively, at something.
To film, shoot.
To become thinner towards the edges.
Any of several cereal grains, of the genus Triticum, that yields flour as used in bakery.
A light brown colour, like that of wheat.
Wheaten, of a light brown colour, like that of wheat.
The exchange or buying and selling of commodities; especially the exchange of merchandise, on a large scale, between different places or communities; extended trade or traffic.
Social intercourse; the dealings of one person or class in society with another; familiarity.
Sexual intercourse.
An 18th-century French card game in which the cards are subject to exchange, barter, or trade.
To carry on trade; to traffic.
To hold intercourse; to commune.
Senses relating to logic, rhetoric, etc.
Senses relating to music and prosody.
To undergo hardship.
definitions.example: Is anyone here afraid of suffering hardship?

definitions.definition: To feel pain.
definitions.example: At least he didn't suffer when he died in the car crash.

definitions.definition: To become worse.
definitions.example: If you keep partying like this, your school-work will suffer.

definitions.definition: To endure, undergo.
definitions.example: I've been suffering your insults for years.

definitions.definition: To allow.
The condition of someone who suffers; a state of pain or distress.
Experiencing pain.
A very close friend.

definitions.definition: (in plural intimates) Women's underwear, sleepwear, or lingerie, especially offered for sale in a store.
definitions.example: You'll find bras and panties in the women's intimates section upstairs.

definitions.definition: To suggest or disclose (something) discreetly.
definitions.example: He intimated that we should leave before the argument escalated.

definitions.definition: To notify.
definitions.example: I will intimate you when the details are available.

definitions.definition: Closely acquainted; familiar.
definitions.example: He and his sister deeply valued their intimate relationship as they didn't have much else to live for.

definitions.definition: Of or involved in a sexual relationship.
definitions.example: She enjoyed some intimate time alone with her husband.

definitions.definition: Personal; private.
definitions.example: an intimate setting

definitions.definition: Pertaining to details that require great familiarity to know.
Any life form of extraterrestrial or extradimensional origin.
A person, animal, plant, or other thing which is from outside the family, group, organization, or territory under consideration.
A foreigner residing in a country.
One excluded from certain privileges; one alienated or estranged.
To estrange; to alienate.
To transfer the ownership of something.
Not belonging to the same country, land, or government, or to the citizens or subjects thereof; foreign.
definitions.example: alien subjects, enemies, property, or shores

definitions.definition: Very unfamiliar, strange, or removed.
definitions.example: principles alien to our religion

definitions.definition: Pertaining to extraterrestrial life.
The act of coordinating, making different people or things work together for a goal or effect.
The resulting state of working together; cooperation; synchronization.
The ability to coordinate one's senses and physical movements in order to act skillfully.
definitions.example: I'm terrible at sports; I have no coordination.

definitions.definition: (possibly archaic) the state of being equal in rank or power.
(grammar) An equal joining together of two or more phrases or clauses, for example, using and, or, or but.
The reaction of one or more ligands with a metal ion to form a coordination compound.
The act of transmitting, e.g. data or electric power.
The fact of being transmitted.
Something that is transmitted, such as a message, picture or a disease; the sending of such a thing.
The passage of a nerve impulse across synapses.
An assembly of gears through which power is transmitted from the engine to the driveshaft in a motor car / automobile; a gearbox.

The right possessed by an heir or legatee of transmitting to his successor(s) any inheritance, legacy, right, or privilege, to which he is entitled, even if he should die without enjoying or exercising it.
(medicine, biology) The passing of a communicable disease from an infected host individual or group to a conspecific individual or group.
A person following the pursuits of civil life, especially one who is not an active member of the armed forces.
definitions.example: Three civilians were apprehended by the soldiers and taken away in a military vehicle.

definitions.definition: A person who does not belong to a particular group or engage in a particular activity.
definitions.example: The bathroom was for employees only, so no civilians were allowed to use it.

definitions.definition: One skilled in civil law.
A student of civil law at a university or college.
Not related to the military, police or other professions.
definitions.example: He worked as a civilian journalist for ten years before being employed by the public broadcaster.

definitions.definition: To return to life; to become reanimated or reinvigorated.
To return to life; to cause to recover life or strength; to cause to live anew.
definitions.example: Her grandmother refused to be revived if she lost consciousness.

definitions.definition: To recover from a state of oblivion, obscurity, neglect, or depression.
definitions.example: Classical learning revived in the fifteenth century.

definitions.definition: To restore, or bring again to life; to reanimate.
definitions.example: This new paint job should revive the surgery waiting room.

definitions.definition: To raise from coma, languor, depression, or discouragement; to bring into action after a suspension.
To renew in the mind or memory; to bring to recollection; to recall attention to; to reawaken.
definitions.example: The Harry Potter films revived the world's interest in wizardry

definitions.definition: To recover its natural or metallic state, as a metal.
To restore or reduce to its natural or metallic state
definitions.example: to revive a metal after calcination

definitions.definition: The lightest chemical element (symbol H), with an atomic number of 1 and atomic weight of 1.00794.
Molecular hydrogen (H2), a colourless, odourless and flammable gas at room temperature.
An atom of the element.
A sample of the element.
Thin, woven, gauze-like fabric.
A fine transparent silk material, used for veils, etc.; specifically, cloth interwoven with gold or silver threads, or embossed with figures.
A sheet of absorbent paper, especially one that is made to be used as tissue paper, toilet paper or a handkerchief.
Absorbent paper as material.
A group of cells similar in origin that function together to do a specific job.
Web; texture; complicated fabrication; connected series.

definitions.definition: To form tissue of; to interweave.
To make (something) new again; to restore to freshness or original condition.
To replace (something which has broken etc.); to replenish (something which has been exhausted), to keep up a required supply of.
To make new spiritually; to regenerate.
To become new, or as new; to revive.
To begin again; to recommence.
To repeat.
To extend a period of loan, especially a library book that is due to be returned.

definitions.definition: The act of renewing.
An offensive action made immediately after a parried one.
The visible horizontal line or point (in all directions) that appears to connect the Earth to the sky.
definitions.example: A tall building was visible on the horizon.

definitions.definition: The range or limit of one's knowledge, experience or interest; a boundary or threshold.
definitions.example: Some students take a gap year after finishing high school to broaden their horizons.

definitions.definition: The range or limit of any dimension in which one exists.
A specific layer of soil or strata
A cultural sub-period or level within a more encompassing time period.
Any level line or surface.
The point at which a computer chess algorithm stops searching for further moves.
A friend or casual acquaintance.
definitions.example: They have been buddies since they were in school.

definitions.definition: A partner for a particular activity.
definitions.example: drinking buddies

definitions.definition: An informal and friendly address to a stranger; a friendly (or occasionally antagonistic) placeholder name for a person one does not know.
definitions.example: Hey, buddy, I think you dropped this.

definitions.definition: To assign a buddy, or partner, to.
Resembling a bud.
Obliged, when called upon, to answer (for one’s deeds); answerable.
definitions.example: Every man is accountable to God for his conduct.

definitions.definition: Obliged to keep accurate records (of property or funds).
Liable to be called on to render an account.
Capable of being accounted for; explicable; explainable.
Of or pertaining to an ideology.
Based on an ideology or misleading studies or statistics, especially based on the media or propaganda. Not based on scientific evidence or reality.
By it; by that; by that means, or as a consequence of that.
Self-government; freedom to act or function independently.
The capacity to make an informed, uncoerced decision.
The capacity of a system to make a decision about its actions without the involvement of another system or operator.
The status of a church whose highest-ranking bishop is appointed by the patriarch of the mother church, but which is self-governing in all other respects. Compare autocephaly.
To bring (items) to an equipoise, as the scales of a balance by adjusting the weights.
To make (concepts) agree.
To hold (an object or objects) precariously; to support on a narrow base, so as to keep from falling.
definitions.example: I balanced my mug of coffee on my knee.

definitions.definition: To compare in relative force, importance, value, etc.; to estimate.
(dancing) To move toward, and then back from, reciprocally.

definitions.definition: To contract, as a sail, into a narrower compass.
definitions.example: to balance the boom mainsail

definitions.definition: To make the credits and debits of (an account) correspond.
definitions.example: This final payment, or credit, balances the account.

definitions.definition: To be in equilibrium.
To have matching credits and debits.
To weigh in a balance.
To hesitate or fluctuate.
Containing elements in appropriate proportion; proportionately weighted on all dimensions and therefore unlikely to tip over.
definitions.example: He believed he rarely got sick because of his balanced diet.

definitions.definition: A state of discomfort arising from bashfulness or consciousness of having violated a social rule; humiliation.
A state of confusion arising from hesitation or difficulty in choosing.

definitions.definition: A large collection of good or valuable things, especially one that exceeds requirements.
Impairment of function due to disease: respiratory embarrassment.
Difficulty in financial matters; poverty.
To render unable; to take away an ability of, as by crippling.
(chiefly of a person) To impair the physical or mental abilities of; to cause a serious, permanent injury.
definitions.example: Falling off the horse disabled him.

definitions.definition: To deactivate, to make inoperational (especially of a function of an electronic or mechanical device).
definitions.example: The pilot had to disable the autopilot of his airplane.

definitions.definition: One who is disabled. (often used collectively as the disabled, but sometimes also singular)
Made incapable of use or action.
Having a disability.
Legally disqualified.
A direct popular vote on a proposed law or constitutional amendment. The adposition on is usually used before the related subject of the vote.
An action, choice, etc., which is perceived as passing judgment on another matter.
definitions.example: My father is taking my decision on whether to go to university as a referendum on his performance as a parent, and it's very stressful.

definitions.definition: The act or result of stirring (moving around the particles of a liquid etc.)
definitions.example: Can you give the soup a little stir?

definitions.definition: Agitation; tumult; bustle; noise or various movements.
Public disturbance or commotion; tumultuous disorder; seditious uproar.
Agitation of thoughts; conflicting passions.
To incite to action
To disturb the relative position of the particles of, as of a liquid, by passing something through it; to agitate.
definitions.example: She stirred the pudding with a spoon.

definitions.definition: To agitate the content of (a container), by passing something through it.
definitions.example: Would you please stand here and stir this pot so that the chocolate doesn't burn?

definitions.definition: To bring into debate; to agitate; to moot.
To change the place of in any manner; to move.
To move; to change one’s position.
To be in motion; to be active or bustling; to exert or busy oneself.
To become the object of notice; to be on foot.
To rise, or be up and about, in the morning.
Jail; prison.
definitions.example: He's going to be spending maybe ten years in stir.

definitions.definition: (collective) A collection of people; a number; a multitude (in general).
A small unit of cavalry or armour commanded by a captain, corresponding to a platoon or company of infantry.
A detachment of soldiers or police, especially horse artillery, armour, or state troopers.
Soldiers, military forces (usually "troops").
A company of stageplayers; a troupe.
A basic unit of girl or boy scouts, consisting of 6 to 10 youngsters.
(collective) A group of baboons.
A particular roll of the drum; a quick march.
Mushrooms that are in a close group but not close enough to be called a cluster.
To move in numbers; to come or gather in crowds or troops.
To march on; to go forward in haste.
To move or march as if in a crowd.

definitions.definition: A mixed alcoholic beverage.
A mixture of other substances or things.
definitions.example: Scientists found a cocktail of pollutants in the river downstream from the chemical factory.

definitions.definition: A horse, not of pure breed, but having only one eighth or one sixteenth impure blood in its veins.
A mean, half-hearted fellow; a coward.
A species of rove beetle, so called from its habit of elevating the tail.
To adulterate (fuel, etc.) by mixing in other substances.
To treat (a person) to cocktails.
definitions.example: He dined and cocktailed her at the most exclusive bars and restaurants.

definitions.definition: Ostentatiously lacking in manners.
An arrangement, categorization or classification of things.
A disposing of or getting rid of something.
The power to use something or someone.
The state of attending; presence or waiting upon.
definitions.example: Attendance at the meeting is required.

definitions.definition: The count or list of individuals present for an event.
definitions.example: The class sat down so that the teacher could take attendance.

definitions.definition: The frequency with which one has been present for a regular activity or set of events.
definitions.example: John's attendance for the conventions was not good.

definitions.definition: Attention paid to something; careful regard.
A parliamentary train.
Of, relating to, or enacted by a parliament
definitions.example: Parliamentary procedures are sometimes slow.

definitions.definition: Having the supreme executive and legislative power resting with a cabinet of ministers chosen from, and responsible to a parliament.
definitions.example: Britain is a parliamentary democracy.

definitions.definition: Of a class of train which, by an act of parliament, ran both ways along a line, at least once each day, at the rate of one penny per mile.
An act of retiring; withdrawal.
The state of being retired; seclusion.
A place of seclusion or privacy; a retreat.
The state of having permanently left one's employment, now especially at reaching pensionable age; the portion of one's life after retiring from one's career.
The act of leaving one's career or employment permanently.
The principal current in a flow, such as a river or flow of air
(usually with the) That which is common; the norm.
definitions.example: His ideas were well outside the mainstream, but he presented them intelligently, and we were impressed if not convinced.

definitions.definition: To popularize, to normalize, to render mainstream.
To become mainstream.
To educate (a disabled student) together with non-disabled students.
definitions.example: Mainstreaming has become more common in recent years, as studies have shown that many mainstreamed students with mild learning disabilities learn better than their non-mainstreamed counterparts.

definitions.definition: Used or accepted broadly rather than by small portions of a population or market.
definitions.example: They often carry stories you won't find in the mainstream media.

definitions.definition: The act of contradicting.
definitions.example: His contradiction of the proposal was very interesting.

definitions.definition: A statement that contradicts itself, i.e., a statement that makes a claim that the same thing is true and that it is false at the same time and in the same senses of the terms.
definitions.example: There is a contradiction in Clarence Page's statement that a woman should have the right to choose and decide for herself whether to have an abortion, and at the same time she should not have that right.

definitions.definition: A logical inconsistency among two or more elements or propositions.
definitions.example: Marx believed that the contradictions of capitalism would lead to socialism.

definitions.definition: A proposition that is false for all values of its variables.
A practitioner of physic, i.e. a specialist in internal medicine, especially as opposed to a surgeon; a practitioner who treats with medication rather than with surgery.
A medical doctor trained in human medicine.
Statements made by a witness in court.
An account of first-hand experience.
In a church service, a personal account, such as of one's conversion.
Witness; evidence; proof of some fact.
A device that controls or limits something.
definitions.example: The voltage regulator stopped working and the resulting overload destroyed the device.

definitions.definition: A person or group that sets standards of practice, especially those established by law.
A very accurate clock, used by clockmakers to measure the timekeeping of each newly made clock.
A gene involved in controlling the expression of one or more other genes.
A device that controls the supply of steam to the cylinders of a steam locomotive.
A bulldozer (member of intimidating group of white US Southerners).
Marijuana, typically of high quality.
A condition of extended duration, either continuous or marked by frequent recurrence. Sometimes implies a condition which worsens with each recurrence, though that is not inherent in the term.
A person who is chronic, such as a criminal reoffender or a person with chronic disease.
Of a problem, that continues over an extended period of time.
definitions.example: chronic unemployment; chronic poverty; chronic anger; chronic life

definitions.definition: Prolonged or slow to heal.
definitions.example: chronic cough; chronic headache; chronic illness

definitions.definition: Of a person, suffering from an affliction that is prolonged or slow to heal.
definitions.example: Chronic patients must learn to live with their condition.

definitions.definition: Inveterate or habitual.
definitions.example: He's a chronic smoker.

definitions.definition: Very bad, awful.
definitions.example: That concert was chronic.

definitions.definition: Extremely serious.
definitions.example: They left him in a chronic condition.

definitions.definition: Good, great; "wicked".
definitions.example: That was cool, chronic in fact.

definitions.definition: A person named, or designated, by another, to any office, duty, or position; one nominated, or proposed, by others for office or for election to office.

A person or organisation in whose name a security is registered though true ownership is held by another party, called nominator, especially for the purpose of concealing the identity of the nominator.
A person to whom the holder of a copyhold estate surrenders their interest.
A totalitarian leader of a country, nation, or government.
definitions.example: Dictators are always punished eventually.

definitions.definition: A magistrate without colleague in republican Ancient Rome, who held full executive authority for a term granted by the senate (legislature), typically to conduct a war.
A tyrannical boss or authority figure.
A person who dictates text (e.g. letters to a clerk).
